author: {'steamid': '76561198030784015', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11208, 'playtime_forever': 29, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 29, 'last_played': 1708330086}
review:
Ctrl CV is yet another of literally thousands of 2D retro platformers infesting Steam and lowering the average quality of all video games everywhere.  This one is a very basic precision platformer slapped together with the GameMaker Studio construction kit, although I will say this doesn't seem like an asset flip but a genuinely made game.  That doesn't mean it's good. 

The gimmick here is the game is made more difficult by a slew of "clones" of your own character than run around the screen and make the game confusing to play.  Well, it's different, anyway, but just because it's different doesn't mean it was a good idea.  Apart from that artificial difficulty, it's just a plain boring platformer, although it does have a very large number of offputting shortcomings and technical defects. 

From a technical perspective, the game doesn't meet basic minimum requirements that most PC gamers expect as standard.

A choice was made to use obsolete, decades old retro pixel "art" as a substitute for contemporary PC graphics.  It's unclear if this is due to lack of budget or talent, regardless, the overall visual quality of the game is extremely low as a result.

There's no option to change the resolution and no useful graphics tweaks.  There's no way to ensure this is running at the native resolution of your display.  There's no guarantee this game will look right on any PC as a result of this hamfisted design decision.

The game only displays in 4:3 pillarboxed aspect ratio.  It's possible they developed this using an old CRT they found in a dumpster, or this game has been specifically designed for people gaming on PC's from 1995... either way, this isn't really acceptable in the modern era of PC gaming.

Bewilderingly, the game doesn't include proper audio controls, so you can't turn off the annoying background music, you'll need to alt+tab out and stop the music using the Windows sound mixer.  This is obviously not okay and it's unclear why the developers chose not to include this basic feature.

The controls can't be customised, which will be an annoyance for many, but it can also render the game unplayable for differently-abled gamers, left handed gamers or gamers using AZERTY or other international keyboard layouts.    To make matters worse, there's no mouse input, despite this being sold on PC as if it were a PC game.  This is unacceptable and somewhat insulting to PC gamers.  It's a good demonstration of the poor attitude the developer has towards PC gamers, and this attitude has resulted in yet another defect in this game.

While this is on PC, it has all the hallmarks and deficiencies of a console game, from the clunkier than needed control scheme to the less than cutting edge graphics.  There's 10's of thousands of PC games on Steam, and PC gamers deserve only the best.  This might not appeal to many gamers due to the lack of PC-centric design.  It's unclear why this game was never accepted on the video game console appliances it seems to have been designed for.

Some of the defects in the game can be attributed to the choice of using the GameMaker Studio construction kit/toolset.  This is a very poor quality toolset favoured by amateur developers as it's cheap and requires little in the way of development skill, but unfortunately has very limited capabilities.  Just as you can't make a silk purse out of a sows ear, you can't make a great video game if you use a terrible engine.  GameMaker Studio is most commonly used to make retro pixel shovelware and cash grabs.

A strong argument can be made that construction kits like GameMaker Studio should never be used to make games for profit, as the "developer", ZPink has done here.  These construction kits are intended to teach people some of the basic principles of game development, and to make small demos to pass around with friends.  They're not intended to replace to actual work of real, professional game developers.  So it's inappropriate when amateurs try to use these for profit, without any actual, real game development effort taking place.  This doesn't result in products that have any real meaningful value for gamers.

These technical defects push this game below acceptable standards for any modern PC game.

The game never really caught on with the millions of gamers on Steam, with a very low peak player count close to launch, and then just a handful of players launching this game every couple of days.  This is undoubtedly caused by factors such as those raised in this review.  It's always helpful with buying decisions to consider how popular and successful the product is, and unfortunately while this did accumulate a few participation trophy reviews, overall, people just aren't using it.

Ctrl CV is relatively cheap at $1 USD, but it's not worth it. Given the defects and quality issues with the game, coupled with the unrealistic price, this is impossible to recommend.  This is also competing with over 9,000 free games available on Steam, many of them far better than this paid product.

review:
[i] Ctrl CV[/i] – платформер. Главная фишка – это мешающие клоны. Самые обыкновенные локации становятся чуточку сложнее из-за того, что надо найти своего героя. review:
This game is designed to be annoying:
  * Level design is super punitive:
    ** If you made a mistake on the puzzling, you are forced to suicide to continue. Learn from Portal.
    ** Most levels you start going in certain direction from the previous one and the game takes advantage of that to put a pit (or spikes) as soon as you enter.
  * You can't get rid of the music.
  * There is no pause menu.
  * Saves are made only at the start of a chapter, not at the start of a level.
  * If you hit ESC you loose your progress without warning.
  * Screen blackouts are the most annoying game mechanic I've ever seen in a game. You have to memorize the level and count the time of turrets shooting. This is important because in some spots bullets are impossible to dodge.
  * Resolution is fixed, and to make things worse, to a 4:3 ratio.
  * You can observe other technical details, such as cannons (turrets?) using global timers, which breaks the immersion.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072279725', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 115, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 72, 'last_played': 1578760038}
review:
[h1]あれ？俺いまどこにいるんだっけ？[/h1]

「自分の残像が大量に湧くことで[b]自機の位置がめちゃくちゃ分かりづらい[/b]」というユニークな特徴を持つ2Dプラットフォーマーだ！

最初のうちは単純にトゲと落とし穴を避けながら先に進んでいくだけ。ステージだけ見たらすげー簡単そう！
なのに、他の人の残像に紛れるといつの間にかトゲを踏んでいる。ジャンプ台に乗れたと思ったら乗れてない。
おっかしーな、今ここにいると思ってたんだけど……。
とはいえ残像は普通に横移動しながら段を登ったり降りたりするだけなので、冷静に垂直ジャンプしてれば完全に見失うこともない、というほどよいバランス。まぁそんなことしてる余裕があるかは別として。

[h2]good[/h2]

* 自機が分かりづらい特徴とステージギミックの相性がすごくいい
* 終盤までは死亡判定が床のトゲか落とし穴しかなく、操作ミスでしか死なないので「これは俺のせい」と納得感が得られやすい。[b]終盤までは[/b]
* ステージデザインも良い。うっかり引っかかりそうなところにトゲがあったり、スイッチを押す順番を考えさせられたり
* 小粒なサイズ。自分はノーマル初見クリアまでに72分、150デスぐらいだった
* 後半になるとだんだん慣れてきて、大量の残像の中でも自由に動き回れるようになるのが気持ちいい

[h2]bad[/h2]

* 「自機を見失う」というコンセプト以外のところで死ぬと「そういうゲームじゃねーだろ！」というストレスが溜まる
* 無料クオリティと言われればそれまでだが、グラフィックのやる気は感じられない
* 最後の2ステージは正直良くない。[spoiler]いきなり飛び出てくる矢が死因の9割なので理不尽さを感じる[/spoiler]

無料であればやってみる価値はあると感じたのでGoodにしたが、はっきり言って人は選びそう。
とりあえず触れてみて、合わないと感じたらさっさとアンインストール、ぐらいがちょうどいいかも。

review:
TL;DR: I'll always recommend fully free games, and surely platform junkies will enjoy it, even if just for a while.

This is a simple platform game. Simple graphics, simple mechanics. Only one thing stands out: there are hundreds of copypasted yous around, ready to distract you. Miss a jump? You were not looking at you, but at another you.

Sadly, it does seem that's the only novelty. I don't mind the graphics, which are a bit crude, or the silly chiptune music. It really has nothing else, besides dozens of copies of your avatar to distract you. It feels amateurish, which sometimes is not a bad thing, but in this case it's not good. I didn't advance much, but having to set fullscreen each time the game loads doesn't thrill me much to keep digging into it to see what the next screen has (for now, only more jumps).

So, check it, it might be your cup of tea, but don't expect much.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025149225', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 35, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 35, 'last_played': 1553966037}
review:
tl;dr A good proof of concept that circles the rage game drain

The concept is solid with the copies and the inability to tell who you are. There's a good change up to the formula with obscuring the player and clones, then obscuring the whole screen for brief flashes, and even obscuring the whole screen for extended periods. But the game falls back on tried and true rage mechanics: spikes and pitfalls that randomly start each level for no other reason than to get your goat right off; spike shooters that  track you and just make it so you can't stop and examine the course (which first show up during the long blackout segments with no attempt at acclimating the player before that), a death counter, ice that functions more like a conveyor belt (this could have been one long factory and that would have been better in design), box physics that are pixel perfect, platforming that's pixel perfect. It's just a mess.

review:
Started out decently enough. Ended horribly. The game's challenge turned from trying not to mix up your movement's with a clone's, to trying to solve block puzzles with limited visibility while simueltaniously dodging shots in narrow corridors with floor spikes every two steps. And if you push that block just a pixel too far, it might not land correctly, and with no way of pushing it back from the other side. I honestly had at least 50 deaths between the game's last save point and the end, and zero of them were because of the game's advertised gimmick of there being too many of me.

The game also has a Hard mode, which I did not play more than a minute of, but the main difference seems to just be less uses of the "locate my character" option. Which I never needed on Normal anyways, since there are some things the clones never do, like stand in place. There was also a Time Trial mode, for the truly masochistic. But I'd rather be happy than frustrated, and if you're the same, then I suggest avoiding this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197976144500', 'num_games_owned': 509, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 71, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 71, 'last_played': 1537213836}
review:
This is a decent game for being free, but it ended up being frustrating due to a few design issues that seem as if they would be fairly simple to correct for.

Pros:
- Great music. It doesn't get old by the time you rage quit.
- Art is okay. It's not distracting, and it seems kinda fluid. There are a few areas where it's not designed well, but the art itself isn't so bad.
- The blizzard/"white out" effect is pretty decent. The special effect is smooth, looks nice, and it has a decent sound to boot.

Cons:
- Player jump sound effect (which you'll be hearing quite frequently) sounds like it was pulled from a 1997 kids game for something you click on in the background. It's loud, annoying, sounds awful in a cartoonish way. Of all things, this game could sound great, but this seems like an easy thing to fix to keep this game from feeling absolutely awful.
- Bad level design:
- - Too often the player starts out in an area that is unsafe. Big nono. Always give the player a safe area to start in. In some instances if you don't stop moving RIGHT at the end of the previous level, you immediately die on the next level.
- - More headroom needed for springboards - the character bounces his head unnaturally off of the ceiling of many areas with platforms. Platforming with springboards in general could feel a lot better, but at least give the player enough headroom.
- - "Stalemate" situations - Player is often stuck in an area in which he cannot go anywhere to proceed and only has to die to continue. It's pretty obvious why this game included a hotkey (always displayed on the screen) to force the player to kill the main character.
- Bad game design:
- - Primary game mechanic that separates this game from the pack is the "clones" which appear right away in the game, and don't ever seem to let up other than in a few (far too short) instances. They could be varied a lot more, to some far greater degree of designed effect. Without pulling off this mechanic, the game might as well be a typical non-noteworthy platformer which it feels like anyway (as soon as you adjust to the clones, because they never vary the way or speed in which they move).
- - Tree areas - old MS-DOS games were rife with the tree areas like this game has. This game seems to not have learned that players don't love these. ESPECIALLY when they're handled just like this game handled them. You can't tell if you collide with any angle of branches or the tree's trunk until you die to learn. Completely unintuitive.
- - Ice - Game has nearly no concept of inertia or momentum until you hit the ice, which behaves oddly. It seems like as long as the last platform you were "grounded" on you are constantly moving forward in whichever direction the character is facing. This feels awkward and bad.
- - Lightswitch mechanism is unintuitive and confusing at first. The blinking of lights also seems to cause headaches, it should kinda strobe out maybe (similar to whiteout in blizzard areas). Could also blink/flash when switch was activated.
- - Dart launchers - This is what made me rage quit. The difficulty spikes up so fast, and they aren't introduced smoothly into gameplay. Everything feels thrown at you all at once. They don't give the player any level of anticipation or allow you to understand the regularity/pattern in which they are fired. They also don't seem to kill the clones which the spikes do, so this seems confusing and/or inconsistent.

review:
I haven't finished the game, and I can't bother either. It's a decent attempt for someone experimenting with game-making.  The main gimmick of the game is and only is the fact you can get lost in a sea of identical clones of you, the player. Other than that there is nothing new when it comes to platforming games. You have platforms to run along, buttons to push to make (road)blocks disappear, springs to jump on, - and maybe turrets to avoid, according to others. The level and visual design are lackluster. Story non-existant as far as I am concerned. 
I imagine this would be a better game if it involved "I wanna be the guy" -types of troll gimmicks and unexpected traps. Gravity and spring mechanics could also be tweaked. Both feel kind of bland and soulless atm.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055311780', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 186, 'playtime_forever': 26, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26, 'last_played': 1534105825}
review:
Join Kyo Kusanagi and relive the NESTS saga!
[quote][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/8257320/]Be sure to leave a like, comment and join Grumpy Reviews[/url][/quote]
A simple idea executed in a mostly simple way Ctrl CV wont scratch that platforming itch for the simple reason it gets a bit too hard in the wrong way. Platformers like Mario are king of the hill for the simple reason that they give you a few chances to mess up before whisking you back to the start whereas here we seemingly have Ninja Gaiden (NES) inspired levels the further in you get. 

As many of my long time readers will know, I am a former US marine who survived World War 1, 2, 3, Vietnam, Sandyhook and even standing on Lego so with reflexes like mine I never once lost sight of my character. Here is a pro-tip to help you do the same, your character is the only one who is [i]not[/i] smiling. Instead for me the challenge came from not having controller support.

Joy2key exists but I played the game as it was intended and let me tell you, if you have a standard non switch keyboard as most of us probably do then their is a good chance you will die due to keyboard unresponsiveness. 
Thankfully levels are short so this isn't a huge hinderence but as i said earlier, it is annoying when it happens and after looking at the same stage for 6 or 7 minutes having made no progress you will give up.

I made it to the ice world part 2 where the screen intentionally whites out every 7 seconds and called it a day. Its not that I couldn't beat those levels had I pushed hard enough but it is more that I didn't see the point. I got the games gimmick and I applaud its originality but spikes and platform switches have been done in other, better games.

However do not mistake that for me thinking this game is bad! It isn't. The music is great and I kept playing just to hear more of it, make it a separate buyable DLC please!
I say try it for yourself, I welcome more original takes on old game ideas and even without the visual gimmick the game works as a mediocre platformer too. I hope the developer tries their hand again in the future.

Phew, I made it the whole review without mentioning the plotline is stolen from King of Fighters '99!

review: A decent game if you're bored (plus it's free!) but it's definitely not perfect. Overall it's a fairly simple platformer with the fun twist that the screen is filled with copies of you, and that's a great concept! What makes the game not as enjoyable in my opinion is how some levels/jumps feel really cheap and feel artificially difficult (ex:invisible pitfalls hidden behind bushes, obnoxious ice levels) but it's not the end of the world. Every new area has it's own gimmick, for example turrets or my personal favorite, a flashing screen every few seconds that messes up every jump. I never actually reached the full end of the game as I got stuck on a level in particular that's not only really difficult with some super precise timings but also requires planning and performing actions in a certain order, but i'll beat it someday. Overall though, Ctrl CV is a pretty fun game to kill time, especially if you like difficult games. Plus, it's free, so what do you really have to lose?

review:
Este juego me llamó la atención, su jugabilidad es bastante innovadora. 
Es simple, tenemos que cruzar un mundo lleno de copias de nosotros mismos e intentar no confundirnos con los clones, ya que tendremos que prestar atención para no perder a nuestro personaje de vista y que se confunda con los demás.
No pensaba que los clones afectaban tanto en los niveles , pero sí, cuando ves tantos clones pasando de un lado para otro ya no sabes ni a que personaje estás controlando y por lo tanto terminas en los pinchos "mágicamente". 
Un juego recomendado, para jugar un ratito xD

review:

Pros:

- The orientation between clones is original and truly based on skill

Cons:

- Lacks polish, you advance one pixel when landing while moving
- Lack of sound effects to orientate and help with timing
- A lot of big offenders on good platform design, including:
> Excessive edge jumping
> trampoline vertical 'off and in' jumping
> Point blank cannon placement
> Buttons that you don't know the use until too late
- Hidden and almost invisible spikes...

review:
It was interesting at first, but during the factory levels, it lost its quality. Turrets fire during black-outs a lot of times, not even giving you a chance to evade. It's all a gamble by then. Easy and hard mode aren't much different. By the time you get to the factory levels, the clones aren't really a problem in either mode and the whole point of the game is not even there anymore. Instead, you get unfair black-outs as a replacement. It goes from needing good sight to needing luck. The game seems to become worse as it goes on. I never was even able to complete the factory levels. The start was decent though, as the clones actually were relevant then. Even if you take the factory out of the equation, it is filled with cheap deaths such as pitfalls and spikes at the beginning of the level that kill you before you can know what is going on if you start out moving (which you probably would be). 

The main difference in hard mode are that the effects of clones linger longer and last more levels, and the reduction of save points between levels. Lack of save points only forces the player to continue playing the game when the player should be going to bed, but he cannot, for if he does, he'll have to pass through unfair spike turrets again. This lack does nothing for the game. The point of platformers isn't to make the player rage, but to have fun, and this lacking is nothing but annoying.

review: The problem with [url=http://tvtropes.org/pmwiki/pmwiki.php/Main/FakeDifficulty]fake-difficulty[/url] games is that they aren't enjoyable to play; this game is no exception. All the difficulty in this game doesn't come from the precision platforming, but rather all the interface-screws that come with it. The clones are fine, but the later level's constant whiteouts/blackouts that completely remove your vision for brief moments, as well as turrets that fire projectiles at you periodically in cramped spaces that require you to go near said turrets to minimize/nullify any chance of being able to evade their projectiles that you often can't see because of the aforementioned blackouts is just not fun. The only redeeming quality about this b-game is that it's free.

review:
Fun, except for the last few levels, which were obviously not tested due to their obscene difficulty. The cannons are too unpredictable, firing every 5000ms with no visual cues. On top of that, there's a puzzle to solve while dodging missiles, with no way to pause. (The "tower" is the last level.)

The gimmick of the 'clones' is interesting but does not add much to the game past the first few levels.

Prepare to be trolled by walking off the ledge immediately after beating a level because you're still holding the arrow key.

It's worth it if you like platformers and have a few hours to kill. Overall it's good but has some level design flaws.
